description.en: Quality of health services and patient-centred health care: concepts and principles. Clinical health promotion, health service standards 2 and 3 of health-promoting hospitals: supporting and informing, empowering patients. Collecting and analyzing feedback from health care users and planning development activities for service improvement in co-operation with a team.
description.et: Tervishoiuteenuste kvaliteet ja patsiendikeskne tervishoid: mõisted ja põhimõtted. Kliiniline tervisedendus, tervist edendavate haiglate terviseteenuste standardid 2 ja 3: patsientide toetamine, informeerimine ja sekkumine/võimestamine. Tervishoiuteenuste kasutajatelt tagasiside kogumine ja analüüsimine ning arendustegevuse kavandamine teenuse parendamiseks koostöös meeskonnaga.

objectives.en: To develop an understanding of the principles and efficiency of patient-centred health care, and to develop the skills, including co-operation skills to evaluate health services patient-centredness and design patient-centred services.
objectives.et: Kujundada arusaam patsiendikeskse tervishoiu põhimõtetest ja tulemuslikkusest ning arendada oskusi, sh koostööoskusi tervishoiuteenuste patsiendikesksuse hindamiseks ja patsiendikesksete teenuste kavandamiseks.

learning_outcomes.en: The student who has completed the course:
- understands the principles, possibilities, and importance of patient-centred health care and clinical health promotion;
learning_outcomes.et: - mõistab patsiendikeskse tervishoiu ja kliinilise tervisedenduse põhimõtteid, võimalusi ning olulisust;

learning_outcomes.en: - has skills to analyse and critically evaluate health services individually and in cooperation with co-students, following the principles of patient-centredness and clinical health promotion;
learning_outcomes.et: - oskab nii iseseisvalt kui ka koostöös kaasõppijatega analüüsida ja kriitiliselt hinnata tervishoiuteenuseid, lähtudes patsiendikesksuse ja kliinilise tervisedenduse põhimõtetest;

learning_outcomes.en: - is able within a team to design a quality program/development plan for the improvement of health services.
learning_outcomes.et: - oskab meeskonnas töötades planeerida kvaliteediprogrammi/tegevuskava tervishoiuteenuste arendamiseks.

notes.et:
If a student is absent from the first seminars, a reflection task from Moodle (assignment No. 4) has to be done as a supplementary task. It consists of submitting an essay summarising all case analyses (5) (according to the general assessment criteria).

NB! 
* The course is in English when at least 4 foreign students participate.
* The forms of learning and teaching can be changed during the course depending on the learning needs of participating students.

independent_work.et:
Independent work (59 hours):
- Reading materials and reflecting them in a Moodle - 19 hours
- Reading case descriptions (Soovituslikud õppematerjalid) and preparing to present and discuss the problems of the case descriptions as a pair or group work - 4 hours;
- Drawing up a group work and PowerPoint presentation - activity plan for improving services in a particular field of health care - 36 hours
*****************************************************************
Guidelines for independent work are accessible in Moodle.

*****************************************************************

description.et:
Assignment No. 3
A written paper "Development plan of a patient-centered service" prepared as group work in accordance with the guidelines (accessible in Moodle) and its oral presentation in a seminar.  The general assessment criteria of the paper are the following:
* The paper presents a general description of the healthcare service selected for development, which is explained on a process-by-step basis, a matrix and a flowchart are attached.
* The process description (including the matrix and flow chart) shows the service bottlenecks based on the principles of healthcare quality, including patient-centeredness.
* A fishbone diagram has been used to analyze the causes of problem areas in the health care service.
* The selected quality criteria and objectives are based on the results of the critical analysis and seek to eliminate the bottlenecks and identified problem causes.
*  In order to achieve the quality goals, it is planned to involve specialists from special fields, cooperate and, if possible, integrate services.
*  The oral presentation is given by the group in the seminar.

grade_preconditions.et: Uploading independent and group work in Moodle on time.

grade_evaluation.et: Formation of the final result: the subject will be passed if the student has applied assignment No. 2 or No. 4, assignment No 1. and assignment No. 3.

debt_elimination.et: Possible problems which may have an influence on the final result has to be discussed by independent consultation with the responsible lecturer and they must be cleared by the last seminar.

resources.mandatory_materials:
* Bélanger, L., Bussières, S., Rainville, F., Coulombe, M., Desmartis, M. (2017). Hospital visiting policies - impacts on patients, families and staff: A review of the literature to inform decision making. Journal of Hospital Administration, 6(6): 51-62.
* Fulford, K. W. M., Ersser, S., Hope, T. (Eds) (1996). Essential practice in patient-centered care. Blackwell Science, Oxford (chapter 8).
* Jaensch, D., Baker, N., Gordon, S. (2019). Contemporaneous patient and health professional views of patient-centred care: a systematic review. International Journal for Quality in Health Care, 31(10): 165-173.
* The New Haven Recommendations on partnering with patients, families and citizens to enhance performance and quality in health promoting hospitals and health services (http://www.hph-hc.cc/fileadmin/user_upload/HPH_Declarations/New-Haven-Recommendations.pdf)
* Declaration on: Patient-Centred Healthcare, © 2006 IAPO

************************************************
* In addition, tasks and materials referred to and available in the e-learning environment Moodle.

************************************************
CASE DESCRIPTIONS
1) Dill, K. & Gance-Cleveland, B. (2005). With you until the end: Family presence during failed resuscitation. Journal for Specialists in Pediatric Nursing (JSPN), 10(4): 204-207.
2) Fine, R.L. (2010). Keeping the patient at the centre of patient- and family-centred care. Journal of Pain and Symptom Management, 40(4): 621-625.
3) Lineham, K. (2010). Caring for young people with chronic illness: a case study. Paediatric Nursing, 22(1): 20-23.
4) Moran, P. (2011). Patient-centred care: Anna's Story. Professional Case Management, 16(5): 256-257.
5) Van Dell, T. (2011). Patient- and family-centred care in the Neonatal Intensive Care Unit in our own words: One family's story. AACN Advanced Critical Care, 22(4): 298-300.

* What is patient-centred healthcare? A review of definitions and principles. International Alliance of Patients' Organizations (IAPO). London, 2007.
